APPLICATION CHNJC 64686 S1872-2067(25)64686-9 10.1016/S1872-2067(25)64686-9 Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, the Chinese Academy of Sciences Fig. 1 SEM images (A), TEM images (B), AuNP size distributions (C), and XRD patterns (D) of (a) Au/LaMnO3, (b) Au/LaMn0.75Cu0.25O3, (c) Au/LaMn0.5Cu0.5O3, and (d) Au/La2CuO4. Fig. 2 XPS spectra of the Au/LaMnO3 (a), Au/LaMn0.75Cu0.25O3 (b) and Au/La2CuO4 (c) catalysts. (A) La 3d; (B) Au 4f, Mn 3s; (C) O 1s; (D) Mn 2p; (E) Cu 2p; (F) Auger Cu LMM. Fig. 3 H2-TPR profiles of various perovskite-supported Au catalysts and the corresponding perovskite supports (the dashed line). Fig. 4 Ethanol conversion (A), AC selectivity (B) and yield (C) as a function of the reaction temperature, and (D) Arrhenius plots for ethanol oxidation, and (E) a stability test for Au/LaMn0.75Cu0.25O3. Reaction conditions: catalyst 0.06 g, ethanol 5.0 μL min–1, ethanol/O2/N2 = 1/3/36, GHSV = 100000 mL gcat –1 h–1). Fig. 5 XPS spectra of fresh (a) and used (b) Au/LaMn0.75Cu0.25O3 catalysts. (A) La 3d; (B) Au 4f and Mn 3s; (C) O 1s; (D) Mn 2p; (E) Cu 2p; (F) Auger Cu LMM. Fig. 6 Effect of Au loading of the Au/LaMn0.75Cu0.25O3 catalyst (I: 0.95 wt% Au, II: 0.47 wt% Au, III: 0.17 wt% Au) on the activity and selectivity (A) and STY value (B) for the ethanol oxidation. Reaction conditions: catalyst 0.06 g, ethanol 5.0 μL min–1, ethanol/O2/N2 = 1/3/36, GHSV = 100000 mL gcat –1 h–1). Fig. 7 Surface models of optimized Au8 clusters on the (001) surfaces of LaMnO3 (A), LaMnCuO3 (B) and La2MnO4 (C). color coding: blue for La, purple for Mn, red for O, gold for Au, and olive for Cu. Fig. 8 The Mars-van Krevelen mechanism of selective oxidation of ethanol (color codes: dark gray round rectangular: supports; gold: Au; black: C; red: O in ethanol; white: H; pink circle with black border: lattice O; pink circle with white border: absorbed O). The activation energy of each elementary step is indicated, with black, red and green representing values for Au/LaMnO3, Au/LaMnCuO3, and Au/La2CuO4, respectively. Values to the left and right of the vertical bars denote the activation energies in eV of the forward and backward reactions, respectively. Fig. 9 Microkinetics simulations of the ethanol conversion rate (conditions: ethanol/O2/N2 = 1/3/36, P = 1 atm) (A) and the degree of rate control as a function of temperature on Au/LaMnO3 (B), Au/LaMnCuO3 (C) and Au/La2CuO4 (D). Fig. 10 Steady-state surface coverages, reaction orders and apparent activation energy as a function of temperature for Au/LaMnO3 (A,D), Au/LaMnCuO3 (B,E), and Au/La2CuO4 (C,F). Hensen b * Peng Liu a * a Key Laboratory of Material Chemistry for Energy Conversion and Storage (Ministry of Education), Hubei Key Laboratory of Material Chemistry and Service Failure, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan 430074, Hubei, China Key Laboratory of Material Chemistry for Energy Conversion and Storage (Ministry of Education) Hubei Key Laboratory of Material Chemistry and Service Failure School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Huazhong University of Science and Technology Wuhan Hubei 430074 China Key Laboratory of Material Chemistry for Energy Conversion and Storage (Ministry of Education), Hubei Key Laboratory of Material Chemistry and Service Failure, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan 430074, Hubei, China b Laboratory of Inorganic Materials and Catalysis, Department of Chemical Engineering and Chemistry, Eindhoven University of Technology, 5600 MB Eindhoven, the Netherlands Laboratory of Inorganic Materials and Catalysis Department of Chemical Engineering and Chemistry Eindhoven University of Technology 5600 MB Eindhoven the Netherlands Laboratory of Inorganic Materials and Catalysis, Department of Chemical Engineering and Chemistry, Eindhoven University of Technology, 5600 MB Eindhoven, the Netherlands * Corresponding author 1 Contributed to this work equally. Gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) supported on the Cu-doped LaMnO3 perovskites exhibit strong Au-Mn-Cu synergy in the aerobic oxidation of gaseous ethanol to acetaldehyde (AC). The Au/LaMnCuO3 catalysts achieve AC yields exceeding 90% and a space-time yield of 715 gAC gAu –1 h–1 at 225 °C, outperforming reported catalysts. The outstanding performance is attributed to adjacent Cu+ and Mn2+ ions in the perovskite surface, which, together with nearby AuNPs, contribute to the high activity and stability. The best-performing catalyst contains a Cu/Mn ratio of 1/3 in the perovskite. Doping too much Cu into the perovskite leads to metallic Cu, suppressing catalyst performance. Density functional theory (reaction energetics, electronic structure analysis) and microkinetics simulations aided in understanding the synergy between Cu and Mn and the role of AuNPs. The reaction involves two H abstraction steps: (1) O–H cleavage of adsorbed ethanol by the basic perovskite lattice oxygen atom and (2) α-C-H cleavage by AuNPs, yielding AC and adsorbed water. Molecular O2 adsorbs in the oxygen vacancy (OV) formed by water removal, generating a peroxide anion (O2 2–) as the activated oxygen species. In the second part of the catalytic cycle, the basic O2 2– species abstracts the H atom from another ethanol molecule, followed by α-C-H cleavage by AuNPs, AC production, and water removal. Water formation in the second part of the catalytic cycle is the rate-controlling step for Au/LaMnO3 and Au/LaMnCuO3 models. Moderate Cu doping enhances the essential Cu+-OV-Mn2+ sites and lowers the barrier for water formation due to the weaker Cu–O bond than the Mn–O bond. In contrast, excessive Cu doping creates unstable Cu2+-O-Cu2+ sites and shifts the barrier to the α-C-H cleavage. Graphical Abstract The improved catalytic performance of Au/LaMnCuO3 (Mn/Cu=3) in gas-phase selective ethanol oxidation is attributed to the proximity of Cu+-OV-Mn2+ sites to the AuNPs, which enhance O2 activation to form O2 2– and facilitate the rate-controlling step of H2O formation. Keywords Ethanol oxidation Acetaldehyde Gold catalyst LaMnO3 perovskite Copper doping 1 Introduction Replacing fossil fuels with biomass to produce valuable chemicals is of great importance to realizing the sustainability goals of the chemical industry [1]. There is a growing interest in manufacturing acetaldehyde (AC) by ethanol dehydrogenation as an alternative to the conventional ethylene-based Wacker oxidation process [2–4]. Ethanol can be produced at a large scale by biomass fermentation, rapidly becoming cost-competitive [4–7]. Compared to ethanol non-oxidative dehydrogenation, gas-phase oxidative dehydrogenation of ethanol has the advantages of high catalytic activity and resistance to metal sintering and coking at lower reaction temperatures [2,8–11]. Although many catalysts, such as nanostructured carbons [12,13], transition-metal oxides [14–18], and supported metal nanoparticles [19–23] are adequate for the aerobic oxidation of ethanol to AC, these catalysts still suffer from the usual trade-off between activity and selectivity. None of them can achieve >90% AC yield below 250 °C. Thus, developing more efficient catalysts that can improve selective ethanol oxidation at lower temperatures remains challenging. The synergy between active metals and various supports is a common theme in heterogeneous catalysis research [24–26]. Supported Au nanoparticles (AuNPs) and Au-alloy catalysts cover various Au-support and bimetallic synergies in gas-phase ethanol oxidation [27–34]. For instance, bimetallic AuIr/SiO2 [31], AuCu/SiO2 [32] and AuCu/BN [34] catalysts exhibited much higher ethanol oxidation activity than the corresponding monometallic catalysts. However, a common problem for these bimetallic catalysts is the significant CO2 selectivity at the expense of AC selectivity when high ethanol conversion (>90%) is reached. To suppress the complete oxidation of ethanol, exploiting the synergy of the Au active phase with a tailored support offers a promising alternative. The Au-Cu synergy in Au/MgCuCr2O4 [28] and Au/CuSiO3 [30] catalysts has already been shown to lead to high AC yield (>90%) at 250 °C. For Au/MgCuCr2O4, density functional theory (DFT) calculations indicated that ethanol oxidation involves a complex mechanism in which reduced Cu+ surface sites can activate adsorbed O2 into O2 -, resulting in high activity and selectivity at the perimeter interface of AuNPs with the support [35]. Detailed characterization showed that the Cu+ defect sites confined in the MgCuCr2O4 matrix resist reduction to metallic Cu0 species during H2 pre-treatment and ethanol oxidation [28, 36], which is crucial for the Cu+ ⇋ Cu2+ redox cycle and stable Au0-Cu+ synergy. Although the optimal Au/MgCuCr2O4 catalyst achieved a very high AC yield (95%) and space-time-yield (STY ~1245 gAC gAu –1 h–1) with air as oxidant at 250 °C [36], the use of toxic Cr is problematic in practical applications. Since it is favorable to operate oxidative dehydrogenation of ethanol at a relatively low temperature to achieve high AC selectivity and increase catalyst stability, exploring Au-support synergies at lower temperatures is desirable. For instance, MnO2 doped with metal cations [15,16] and therefrom derived supported AuNPs catalysts [37,38] were reported to be effective for the selective oxidation of ethanol. Au/Cu-α-MnO2 [37] and Au/Cu-γ-MnO2 [38] reached a maximum AC yield of 80% and 82% at 200 °C, respectively. However, it is difficult to further enhance the Au-support synergy in such catalysts because of the limited amount of Cu that can be introduced in MnO2 phases [16,39]. LaMnO3-type perovskites have been extensively used in the catalytic combustion of hydrocarbons due to their high activity and thermal resistance [40–42]. Deposition of AuNPs on the LaMnO3 can enhance the activity in low-temperature catalytic combustion [43,44]. Au/LaMnO3-type catalysts have seldom been used in selective oxidation. Given that the redox property of LaMnO3 can be modified by doping with other transition metal cations and high doping levels can be achieved [45–48], this would represent an opportunity to identify novel Au-support synergy between AuNPs and metal-doped LaMnO3 perovskites for selective oxidation of gaseous ethanol. In this work, we demonstrate that Cu-doped LaMnO3 as a support for AuNPs renders excellent Au/LaMnCuO3 (Mn/Cu = 3) catalyst, achieving 98% AC selectivity at 97% ethanol conversion at 225 °C and ambient pressure. This catalyst outperforms the earlier reported optimum catalysts for this reaction and exhibits excellent stability, showcasing a novel synergy between Au, Mn, and Cu. Theoretical calculations indicate preferential formation of oxygen vacancies (OV) at surface Cu2+-O-Mn3+ sites, where O2 is favorably adsorbed and activated on Cu+-OV-Mn2+ motifs via a two-electron-transfer process, leading to the formation of the peroxide anion (O2 2–). O2 2– is the critical reactive oxygen species in ethanol activation on the Au/LaMnCuO3 surface. In comparison to undoped LaMnO3 and La2CuO4-supported Au catalysts, the enhanced catalytic performance of Au/LaMnCuO3 is attributed to active sites that involve metallic Au in close proximity to Cu+-OV-Mn2+ sites. These sites facilitate the rate-controlling step of H2O formation through a mechanism that includes O–H and C–H cleavage reactions, which are mediated by O2–/O2 2– species and Au, respectively. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst synthesis The LaMnO3, LaMn0.75Cu0.25O3, LaMn0.5Cu0.5O3 and La2CuO4 supports were prepared by a sol-gel combustion method. The nitrates containing La3+, Mn2+, and/or Cu2+ in the stoichiometric quantity (La/(Mn + Cu) = 1) for the synthesis of 10 g of the product were dissolved in deionized water (50 mL), followed by addition of citric acid (6 g) and ethylene glycol (3 mL). The resulting solution was evaporated in a sand bath (150 °C). Finally, the gel mixture was ignited to obtain an amorphous precursor, which was calcined in air at 900 °C for 5 h to yield the perovskites. Various supported Au catalysts were prepared by homogeneous deposition-precipitation of HAuCl4 with urea. The targeted gold loading was 1.0 wt%. The catalysts were finally calcined in air at 300 °C for 5 h. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed on an Empyrean apparatus using Cu K α radiation (40 kV and 30 mA). Nitrogen physisorption was done on a Tristar 3000 automated gas adsorption system. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were taken using an FEI Nova NanoSEM 450 microscope. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were acquired on an FEI Tecnai G2 F30 electron microscope. The average size of AuNPs was calculated by measuring ~200 Au particles from several images. The Au loading was determined by a Perkin Elmer AA-300 atomic absorption spectrometer (AAS) after extracting the metal in aqua regia. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) and temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) experiments were performed on Micrometrics AutoChem 2920II instrument. For H2-TPR, the sample was reduced in 10 vol% H2 in Ar at a flow rate of 10 mL min–1, while it was heated from room temperature up to 900 °C at a ramp rate of 10 °C min–1. The acidic and basic properties of perovskites were studied with the TPD of NH3 and CO2, respectively. The sample (50 mg) was pretreated in Ar at 500 °C for 2 h then cooled to 100 °C and saturated with NH3 or CO2 gas in a flow (30 mL min–1) of 0.3% NH3/Ar or 10% CO2/Ar for 1 h, respectively. After that, the sample was flushed with Ar at 100 °C for 1 h to remove physically absorbed NH3 or CO2, followed by heating in Ar from 100 to 500 °C at a rate of 10 °C min–1. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopic (XPS) measurements were conducted on an AXIS-ULTRA DLD-600W spectrometer with Al Kα irradiation. The binding energies were calibrated by setting the C 1s peak of adventitious carbon to 284.5 eV. 2.3 Catalytic activity measurements Ethanol oxidation was carried out in a fixed-bed plug flow reactor at atmospheric pressure. The Au catalyst (60 mg, 150–180 μm) diluted with α-Al2O3 (0.5 g, 180–250 μm) was loaded into a quartz reactor with an internal diameter of 8 mm and a thermal couple inside the catalyst bed. Prior to reaction, the catalyst was treated with O2 at 250 °C for 2 h. Ethanol (5 μL min–1) was pumped into an evaporator at 83 °C together with O2 (7.5 mL min–1) and N2 (90 mL min–1), which resulted in a molar ratio of ethanol/O2/N2 = 1/3/36 in the gas phase. Then the preheated gas mixture was passed through the catalyst bed at a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of ~100,000 mL gcat –1 h–1. The reaction products were analyzed online by GC (Fuli 9070II) equipped with a 30 m RB-InnoWax capillary column and a TDX-01 packed column. In all cases, the carbon balance closed at 100 ± 2%. External and internal mass transport limitations were excluded by using different catalyst weights and particle sizes. The ethanol conversion and AC selectivity were calculated by: Conv. (%) = (total C mol% – 2 × CH3CH2OH mol%)/total C mol% × 100 Selec. (%) = 2 × CH3CHO mol%/(total C mol% – 2 × CH3CH2OH mol%) × 100 2.4 DFT calculations All DFT calculations were performed using the Vienna Ab-initio Simulation Package (VASP) [49–51] employing the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) [52] exchange-correlation functional. The interactions between core electrons and the nuclei were treated using the Projector Augmented Wave (PAW) method [53–55]. A cutoff energy of 400 eV was used. For k-point sampling, only the Γ-point was used. A Gaussian smearing width of 0.05 eV was adopted to determine partial occupancies. The maximum force was set to 0.05 eV Å–1 as a convergence criterion. Van-der-Waals interactions were considered by using the DFT-D3 method with Becke-Jonson damping. Transition states were searched using the climbing image nudge elastic band (CI-NEB) method and verified by the occurrence of a single imaginary frequency in the direction of the reaction coordinate [56]. The Hessian matrix constructed for the vibrational analysis was based on a finite-difference approach by perturbation of the atomic positions by 0.01 Å. Microkinetics simulations based on the reaction energetics determined by DFT were used to investigate the kinetics and mechanistic aspects of the selective oxidation of ethanol to AC over the three surface models. The details of the structural models used and the microkinetics simulations are given in the Supporting Information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts The textural, structural, and chemical properties of the perovskite-supported Au catalysts are summarized in Table 1 . The morphology of these catalysts was examined by SEM (Fig. 1(A) ). Primary perovskite crystals combine into large agglomerates and form macropores. The average crystal size of LaMnO3 was ~80 nm. Adding Cu led to larger crystals, i.e., ~105 nm for LaMn0.75Cu0.25O4 and ~580 nm for La2CuO4. Accordingly, the surface area decreased from 5.3 m2 g–1 for Au/LaMnO3 to 2.2 m2 g–1 for Au/LaMn0.75Cu0.25O4 and 0.5 m2 g–1 for Au/La2CuO4. The dispersion and distribution of AuNPs on the perovskites were evaluated by TEM (Figs. 1(B) and (C)). AuNPs were highly dispersed in all four catalysts. With increasing Cu content and decreasing surface area in the supports, the mean AuNP size increased from 3.0 nm for Au/LaMnO3 to 3.5 nm for Au/LaMn0.75Cu0.25O4 and 6.5 nm for Au/La2CuO4. Fig. S1 shows representative TEM images of the reference catalysts, i.e., Au/MgCuCr2O4, Au/La2O3, Au/β-MnO2 and Au/CuO catalysts, with comparable Au content and AuNP size to the perovskite-supported Au catalysts (Table S1). The formation of perovskite was confirmed by XRD (Fig. S2). These patterns were similar after loading with AuNPs (Fig. 1(D)). Except for Au/La2CuO4, the absence of diffraction lines due to metallic Au is consistent with the high metal dispersion observed by TEM. LaMnO3 and Cu-doped LaMnO3 (LaMnCuO3) exhibit the orthorhombic structure of LaMnO3.11 (#50-0297) [57]. The material obtained by replacing Mn completely by Cu exhibited the orthorhombic structure of La2CuO4 (#82-2098) [58,59], mixed with a small amount of CuO (#45-0937). It is likely that this CuO phase was not completely dissolved in the acidic solution of HAuCl4 during Au deposition. XPS was performed to study the surface chemical state and defects of the perovskite-supported Au catalysts (Fig. 2 ). The La 3d 5/2 and the accompanying satellite peaks observed at 834.0 and 837.8 eV, respectively, belong to La3+ [60]. The Au 4f 7/2 binding energy of ~83.9 eV in all three catalysts points to the presence of metallic Au0 [38]. Four distinct oxygen species can be resolved from the O 1s spectra (Fig. 2(C)). The features at ~529, 531, 532 and 533 eV can be attributed to lattice oxygen (OL), oxygen vacancies (OV), hydroxyl groups or adsorbed oxygen (OA) and surface adsorbed water (OW), respectively [61,62]. With increasing Cu content, the fraction of OL notably decreased from 64% for Au/LaMnO3 to 16% for Au/La2CuO4, while the corresponding (OA + OV)/OL ratio increased from 48.4% to 481.3%. These results indicate that the introduction of Cu in the perovskite structure generates more oxygen vacancies. For the Mn 2p 3/2 spectra, three peaks located at 640.8, 642.0, and 644.0 eV can be fitted, which are assigned to Mn2+, Mn3+ and Mn4+, respectively [63,64]. The fraction of surface Mn3+ species decreased slightly upon Cu doping in LaMnO3. In the Cu 2p 3/2 spectra, Cu+ and Cu2+ species appear at ~932 and ~934 eV, respectively, accompanied by Cu2+ shakeup features (938-946 eV) [32,65]. Auger Cu LMM spectra indicated that ~10% of the surface Cu+ species were present in Au/LaMn0.75Cu0.25O3, whereas no Cu+ defects were observed in Au/La2CuO4, consistent with its low surface area and high crystallinity. The occurrence of significant Cu+ and Mn2+ defect sites in the surface of LaMnCuO3 perovskites may be related to the redox reactions, Cu2+ + Mn3+ → Cu+ + Mn4+ and Cu+ + Mn3+ → Cu2+ + Mn2+ between Cu-oxides and Mn-oxides [66,67]. H2-TPR analysis was employed to assess the redox properties of the perovskites and their corresponding Au catalysts (Fig. 3 ). The introduction of AuNPs onto the supports resulted in a shift of the main reduction feature to lower temperatures, likely due to H2 activation on the AuNPs and the subsequent spillover of H atoms to the support [68]. Typically, Mn2+ and Cu0 are the final oxidation states achieved from the reduction of Mn-oxides and Cu-oxides, respectively. The amounts of reducible species are comparable in the parent perovskites and their Au-loaded counterparts (Table 1). For Au/LaMnO3, the reduction feature observed below 300 °C is attributed to the reduction of surface Mn4+ to Mn3+ or Mn2+ and the removal of surface oxygen, while the feature above 650 °C is likely associated with the reduction of bulk Mn3+ to Mn2+ [43]. For Au/La2CuO4, the reduction peaks can be attributed to the decomposition of La2CuO4 to La2O3 and Cu0. For the Au/LaMnCuO3 catalysts, the first reduction feature likely involves the simultaneous reduction of Mn4+ to Mn3+ and Cu2+ to Cu+. Notably, LaMn0.75Cu0.25O3 exhibits lower reducibility compared to the other perovskites, suggesting that the minor Cu doping in the LaMnO3 enhanced the stability of the reducible Mn and Cu species in a reductive atmosphere. The acid-base properties of the perovskite supports were investigated by NH3/CO2-TPD (Fig. S3). The desorption temperature and peak area provide insight into the strength and quantity of acidic and basic sites, respectively. The primary desorption peaks for the four perovskites appear below 150 °C, indicating that these samples predominantly contain weak acid and base sites. As the Cu content increases, the amounts of acidic sites decrease from 80.7 μmol g–1 for LaMnO3 to 12.1 μmol g–1 for La2CuO4, while the amounts of basic sites decrease from 150.8 to 31.5 μmol g–1 (Table 1). The observed acidity and basicity are attributed to the cations (M n+) and anions (O2 –, O2 2–, O2–) present on the surface of the perovskite materials [69]. Given the promoting effect of solid bases on alcohol dehydrogenation [70,71], the alkaline nature of the perovskite-supported Au catalysts is expected to facilitate selective ethanol oxidation. 3.2 Catalytic performance We initially investigated the support effect on the catalytic performance of various supported Au catalysts in the aerobic oxidation of ethanol, as presented in Table 2 . All catalysts were pretreated at 250 °C in an oxygen atmosphere prior to reaction. At 225 °C, AC was the main reaction product, exhibiting selectivity of up to 99% for all supported Au catalysts, with the exception of Au/LaMnO3 and Au/β-MnO2, which completely oxidized ethanol. Doping Cu into the LaMnO3 perovskite significantly enhanced the productivity towards AC. Notably, Au/LaMn0.75Cu0.25O3 demonstrated much higher catalytic activity than Au/LaMn0.5Cu0.5O3 and Au/MgCuCr2O4, achieving AC yield, STY and turnover frequency (TOF) of 95%, 378 h–1 and 1580 h–1, respectively. In contrast, the Au catalysts supported on unitary oxides (La2O3, MnO2, CuO) and binary oxides (LaMnO3, La2CuO4) exhibited significantly lower AC yields compared to Au/LaMnCuO3, suggesting a lack of effective synergy between the AuNPs and the support in these cases. Figs. 4(A)-(C) illustrates the temperature dependence of ethanol conversion, AC selectivity and yield over the various catalysts. The bare LaMn0.75Cu0.25O3 support exhibited the lowest activity, with AC selectivity gradually decreasing as the temperature increased, resulting in an AC yield of 18% at 250 °C. In contrast, the Au/LaMn0.75Cu0.25O3 catalyst achieved a significantly higher AC yield than the other catalysts within the 100–225 °C temperature range. However, the CO2 selectivity increased substantially at the expense of the AC selectivity above 225 °C. A marked increase in CO2 selectivity was also observed when Au/LaMnO3 was used above 200 °C, consistent with previous studies reporting complete oxidation of toluene over Au/LaMnO3 catalysts [43]. Although the Au/La2CuO4 and Au/MgCuCr2O4 catalysts, which do not contain Mn, can achieve AC yields exceeding 85% at 250 °C, they demonstrate much lower activity at lower temperatures compared to the optimal Au/LaMn0.75Cu0.25O3 catalyst, which attains its maximum AC yield at 225 °C. The superior catalytic performance can be attributed to the synergistic effects of Au, Mn, and Cu within the perovskite structure of LaMn0.75Cu0.25O3. To further elucidate the effect of the support, we examined the kinetics at significantly lower temperatures (100–175 °C) and at lower conversion levels (< 20%). The apparent activation energies (E a) estimated from Arrhenius plots range from 40 to 83 kJ mol–1 (Table 2 and Fig. 4(D)), which aligns with previously reported values of 30 to 80 kJ mol–1 for gas-phase ethanol oxidation over supported Au catalysts [36]. Notably, the E a values correlate inversely with catalytic activity, with the most active Au/LaMn0.75Cu0.25O3 catalyst demonstrating the lowest E a of 40 kJ mol–1. This lower apparent activation energy points to the facile activation of ethanol and O2 reactants on the Au/LaMn0.75Cu0.25O3 catalyst. To assess the stability of the Au/LaMn0.75Cu0.25O3 catalyst, we evaluated the performance in ethanol oxidation over 80 h (Fig. 4(E)). The catalyst was stable at 200 °C for the first 20 h. This stability was maintained under more rigorous conditions at 225 °C for the next 60 h. Throughout this period, ethanol conversion remained consistently high at 97%, with an AC selectivity of 98%. After 80 h on stream, the structure and morphology of the catalyst were largely preserved. The average AuNP size increased slightly from 3.5 to 3.6 nm (Fig. S4). Detailed TEM analysis revealed an alignment of the (111) facet of the AuNPs with the (200) planes of the LaMnCuO3 support. Furthermore, although there was an increase in surface defects, the perovskite structure remained intact. These findings indicate that Au/LaMn0.75Cu0.25O3 is an efficient and stable catalyst for the selective gas-phase oxidation of ethanol to AC. The role of Cu+ species in Au/MgCuCr2O4 has been previously highlighted in terms of facile O2 activation [28,35,36]. Given the advantages conferred by Mn in the catalyst composition, we hypothesize that similar surface defects involving cationic Mn may serve as active sites for O2 activation. 3.3 Evidence for Au-Mn-Cu interaction To better understand the Au-Mn-Cu interactions in the optimal Au/LaMn0.75Cu0.25O3 catalyst, the used catalyst after 80 h on stream was analyzed by XPS (Fig. 5 ). The results indicate that, aside from the La3+ species, all other metal and oxygen species changed their chemical states. Notably, the Au 4f 7/2 binding energy shifted from 84.0 to 83.7 eV, suggesting that metallic Au0 is the active species and that the AuNPs in the used Au/LaMn0.75Cu0.25O3 catalyst are negatively charged. This negative charge may result from electron transfer occurring at the metal-support interface during ethanol oxidation [27]. While the fraction of OL species remained unchanged, the fraction of OV sites slightly decreased from 20% to 18%, accompanied by an increase in the OA fraction from 15% to 18%. These findings suggest that oxygen vacancies and adsorbed oxygen species play significant roles in ethanol oxidation. Furthermore, the surface fraction of Mn2+ increased markedly from 13% to 36%, while the fractions of Mn3+ and Mn4+ decreased from 64% to 45% and 23% to 19%, respectively. The substantial increase in the fraction of Mn2+ species suggests that the Mn2+ defective sites serve as active sites for O2 adsorption and activation. The surface fraction of Cu+ increased from 10% to 18%, and the Auger Cu LMM spectra confirmed that metallic Cu0 was not formed. In contrast, the surface of the used Au/LaMn0.5Cu0.5O3 and Au/La2CuO4 catalysts contained a significant amount of Cu0 (~20%, Fig. S5). The absence of Cu0 species in the used Au/LaMn0.75Cu0.25O3 catalyst suggests that the surface can undergo Mn4+/Mn3+ ⇋ Mn2+ and Cu2+ ⇋ Cu+ redox changes upon oxidation and reduction, aligning with the stable ratio of (OA + OV)/OL during ethanol oxidation, without formation of Cu0. The increase in Mn2+ and Cu+ defect sites may result from Au-promoted support reduction in the presence of ethanol [36]. Furthermore, while fresh Au/LaMnO3 also contains Mn2+ species (Fig. 2), its performance is inferior to Au/LaMn0.75Cu0.25O3 below 225 °C (Fig. 4). Thus, we infer that a strong synergy exists between Au0, Cu+, and Mn2+, which is more advantageous than the interactions between Au0 and Mn2+ or Au0 and Cu+. To correlate the superior catalytic activity of Au/LaMn0.75Cu0.25O3 with its reducibility below 250 °C, this catalyst was pre-reduced in H2 at 250 °C before the reaction. This treatment is expected to generate additional surface Mn2+/Cu+ defect sites and oxygen vacancies, as indicated in Fig. 3. However, the pre-reduced catalyst exhibited significantly lower activity than the pre-oxidized counterpart. While the pre-oxidized catalyst achieved nearly complete ethanol conversion at 225 °C, the conversion dropped to 83% following pre-reduction (Fig. S6). This decline can be attributed to damage to the perovskite structure caused by intense reduction with H2, which led to the formation of surface Cu0 (Fig. S5). Thus, it is likely that a reductive pretreatment decreased the number of Cu+-O-Mn2+ sites at the surface, decreasing the catalytic performance. On the other hand, an oxidative pretreatment is beneficial for Au/LaMn0.75Cu0.25O3, contrasting with the effects observed in Au/MgCuCr2O4 [28,36]. This discrepancy likely arises from the greater reducibility of Cu ions in Au/LaMn0.75Cu0.25O3 (below 250 °C) than that in Au/MgCuCr2O4 (above 300 °C). The Au loading for the Au/LaMn0.75Cu0.25O3 catalyst was further optimized. As illustrated in Fig. S7, the average AuNP size decreased slightly from 3.5 to 3.0 nm as the Au content was reduced from 0.95 wt% to 0.17 wt%. Fig. 6 presents the temperature dependence of the main reaction performance metrics. Although ethanol conversion decreased when the Au loading was lowered, Au/LaMn0.75Cu0.25O3-II (0.47 wt% Au, 3.2 nm) and Au/LaMn0.75Cu0.25O3-III (0.17 wt% Au, 3.0 nm) achieved their maximum AC yield of 91% and 62% at 225 °C, respectively, along with corresponding STY of 732 and 1385 gAC gAu –1 h–1. From a practical perspective, operating at lower AC selectivity is not desirable, even if the STY is high. Therefore, the optimal reaction temperature is determined to be 225 °C, and the synergy between Au, Mn, and Cu can be enhanced by reducing both the Au loading and the AuNP size. It is also important to note that reaction conditions, such as ethanol concentration, can influence the catalytic performance [36,38]. For instance, when the ethanol feed rate increased from 2.5 to 5.0 vol% while keeping other parameters constant, the Au/LaMn0.75Cu0.25O3-I catalyst exhibited a slightly lower AC yield of 90%, but with a much higher STY of 715 gAC gAu –1 h–1 at 225 °C. These STY values are much higher than those reported for state-of-the-art gold catalysts below 250 °C (Table S2), highlighting the advantages of Au/LaMn0.75Cu0.25O3 catalysts for selective ethanol oxidation at lower temperatures. 3.4 DFT calculations To understand the interplay between Au, Mn, and Cu, we combined DFT calculations of the reaction energetics and microkinetic simulations of the selective ethanol oxidation reaction using model surfaces of Au/LaMnO3, Au/LaMnCuO3 and Au/La2CuO4. For the Au/LaMnO3 and Au/La2CuO4 models, Au8 clusters were supported on LaMnO3(001) and La2CuO4(001) surfaces (Figs. S8 and S9), respectively. Au/LaMnCuO3 was modeled by replacing one Mn atom in the surface with a Cu atom. Fig. 7 presents the three surface models employed in the DFT calculations. For the selective oxidation of ethanol on Au supported by reducible oxides, we follow the mechanism established in previous studies involving lattice O atoms through a Mars-van Krevelen mechanism [35,72]. Fig. 8 outlines the key steps in the selective oxidation of ethanol. The basicity of these lattice O atoms is crucial for the dissociation of the OH group in adsorbed ethanol, which leads to a surface-bound OH group and an ethoxy species (R2). The adsorbed ethoxy typically undergoes a rotation to align one of the α-C-H bonds with the Au cluster, facilitating subsequent C-H bond cleavage. This results in a H species on the Au cluster and adsorbed AC (R3). The H atom then reacts with the lattice OH to yield adsorbed H2O (R5). Following H2O desorption, an OV is formed (R6). When O2 adsorbs in this vacancy, it generates a superoxide or peroxide species (R7), which acts as a base and promotes the adsorption of a second ethanol molecule on the surface. This process leads to OH dissociation in ethanol (R9), activation of the α-C-H bond (R10), AC desorption (R11), and the formation and desorption of H2O (R12 and R13), thereby healing the surface OV and completing the catalytic cycle. The energy diagrams illustrating the selective oxidation of ethanol on Au/LaMnO3, Au/LaMnCuO3 and Au/La2CuO4 are provided in Figs. S10–S12, with the corresponding energetics summarized in Table 3 . Given the higher d-band occupancy of Cu, Cu–O bonds should be weaker than Mn–O bonds, which can explain the computed trend in the oxygen vacancy formation energies: Au/LaMnO3 (2.56 eV) > Au/LaMnCuO3 (1.71 eV) > Au/La2CuO4 (1.64 eV). The O–O bond distance of O2 adsorbed in an OV is elongated to 1.45–1.48 Å, which indicates its O2 2– character [73]. We observe that one O atom occupies the oxygen vacancy, while the other one coordinates to a Mn or Cu cation and a Au atom of the Au cluster (R7). The dissociation of the O–H bond in the adsorbed ethanol to this O2 2– species (R9) occurs with activation energies of 0.06 eV for Au/LaMnO3, 0.38 eV for Au/LaMnCuO3, and 0.73 eV for Au/La2CuO4. The abstraction of a proton from the ethanolic O–H bond on a surface lattice O atom (R2) in the first part of the catalytic cycle has activation energies of 0.06 eV for Au/LaMnO3, 0.28 eV for Au/LaMnCuO3, and 0.33 eV for Au/La2CuO4. The activation energy of O-H bond dissociation in ethanol depends on the basicity of O atoms. Lattice O atoms generally exhibit an oxidation state of –2. The adsorbed O2 2– species, on the other hand, tends to dissociate into a lattice O atom which has an oxidation state of –2 and an O atom which acts at the basic site to adopt the dissociated H atom from ethanol. Consequently, the basicity of the adsorbed O2 2– species is weaker than that of lattice O atoms. Cu donates fewer electrons compared to Mn, leading to a decline in base strength in the order Au/LaMnO3 > Au/LaMnCuO3 > Au/La2CuO4 for both lattice O atoms and adsorbed O2 2– species. This descending trend is more pronounced for adsorbed O2 2– species. The kinetic data listed in Table 3 were used to model the selective oxidation of ethanol for the different models. For clarity, we denoted the reaction between ethanol and lattice oxygen atoms as SI and the reaction between ethanol and adsorbed O2 as SII. Fig. 9(A) illustrates the ethanol conversion rates, revealing that a much higher reaction rate is predicted for Au/LaMnCuO3 than for Au/LaMnO3 and Au/La2CuO4. This qualitatively aligns with our experimental observations. The reaction rate is defined here as the ethanol conversion rate per unit cell, each containing one Au8 cluster. Below 330 °C, Au/La2CuO4 shows higher activity than Au/LaMnO3, while the trend reverses at higher temperatures. The apparent activation energy for the Au/LaMnO3 model is different from those determined for the Cu-containing models, suggesting a change in the rate-controlling steps. Additionally, experimental data indicate a higher apparent activation energy for Au/LaMnO3. Fig. 9 also shows the degree of rate control (DRC) analysis for the three surfaces. At low reaction temperatures, the overall reaction rate for Au/LaMnO3 and Au/LaMnCuO3 is mainly controlled by H2O formation in reaction pathway SII, with activation barriers of 1.67 and 0.72 eV, respectively (see R12 of Table 3). This suggests that the lower barrier of H2O formation for the Cu-doped surface is the main reason for the higher activity. Previous DFT calculations dealing with a comparison of a similar reaction mechanism for Au/MgCr2O4 and Au/MgCuCr2O4 catalyst compositions also revealed that Cu doping weakens the bond strength of the OH intermediate to the surface, facilitating H2O formation [35]. Different from our case, a lower H2O formation barrier was predicted for the MgCr2O4-supported Au clusters in SI. For Au/LaMnO3 and Au/LaMnCuO3 under study here, the rate-controlling step is the H2O formation in SII, while for Au/La2CuO4, the overall reaction rate is determined by the C-H bond scission in adsorbed ethoxy in SI, which has a higher activation energy of 0.91 eV (R3) compared to the much lower barrier of 0.57 eV for H2O formation (R12). This difference explains why Au/La2CuO4 exhibits a higher activity than Au/LaMnO3. Figs. 9(B) and (D) show the rate-determining steps for Au/LaMnO3 and Au/La2CuO4 do not depend on the temperature, with significant changes occurring only above 330 °C. For Au/LaMnO3, an increase in the DRC coefficient for C–H bond scission in CH3CH2O (R3) is observed, while for Au/La2CuO4, the DRC coefficient for O–H bond scission in CH3CH2OH (R9) increases with temperature. For Au/LaMnO3, the H2O formation (R12) with a high barrier of 1.67 eV becomes accessible at elevated temperatures, resulting in the preceding C–H bond scission in CH3CH2O* step partially controlling the overall reaction rate. Similarly, for Au/La2CuO4, as the temperature increases, the rate of C–H bond scission (R3) increases, shifting the rate-limiting step to O–H bond scission in CH3CH2OH (R10). Fig. 9(C) indicates that, for Au/LaMnCuO3, several elementary reaction steps, namely R2, R3, and R9, begin to influence the overall rate at temperatures above 180 °C. As the temperature increases above 260 °C, O–H bond scission in CH3CH2OH (R9) becomes the main rate-limiting step. We discuss the surface coverages shown in Fig. 10 in terms of the rate-controlling steps for the different models. For the Au/LaMnO3 and Au/LaMnCuO3 surfaces, the high barriers for H2O formation (R12) lead to a high contribution of the H*OH* surface state in the low-temperature regime. For Au/La2CuO4 where C–H bond scission (R3) is the rate-limiting step, the empty surface (*) emerges as the most abundant surface intermediate. This can be attributed to the relatively low barrier for the reverse reaction R2 and the entropy gain upon ethanol desorption. For all models, the surface becomes richer in vacant sites and oxygen vacancies with increasing temperature. The dependence of the reaction rate on temperature and reactant partial pressures is described in Figs. 10(D)–(F). The apparent activation energies reflect the energy difference between the most abundant state and the transition state of the rate-determining step. For multiple rate-controlling steps, the apparent activation energy corresponds to the weighted sum of these energy differences, the weights being the DRC coefficients [74]. For Au/LaMnO3 and Au/LaMnCuO3, the apparent activation energy aligns with the activation energy of R12. For Au/La2CuO4, the apparent activation energy can be derived from the energy difference between the initial empty state and the transition state of reaction R3. As temperature increases, the apparent activation energy decreases, which is due to the increasing abundance of empty sites. The surface states with vacancies represent less stable states compared to the most abundant surface intermediates at low temperatures. The reaction orders for Au/LaMnO3 in the low-temperature regime are zero with respect to ethanol and O2, in line with the prediction that the surface is fully covered with these reactants. With increasing temperature, there are more empty sites and the reaction becomes more dependent on the C–H bond scission step in the CH3CH2O* intermediate. As this step requires at least one ethanol molecule to be adsorbed onto an empty site, a positive reaction order in ethanol is observed, which correlates with the DRC coefficient for C–H bond scission. Similarly, for Au/LaMnO3, reaction orders of zero in ethanol and O2 are predicted in the low-temperature regime. At higher temperatures, several O–H and C–H bond scission steps from ethanol-derived intermediates become rate-controlling, leading to a higher reaction order in ethanol. At elevated temperatures, a positive reaction order for O2 is computed, which is due to the increased availability of OV* necessary for O2 adsorption for the rate-limiting steps to proceed. For Au/La2CuO4, a reaction order of approximately unity in ethanol is observed, regardless of the temperature. As the dominant surface states are either empty sites or OV*, at least one ethanol molecule is adsorbed to reach the transition state for these rate-limiting steps. At low temperatures, the reaction order in O2 is zero. As temperature increases, this reaction order rises due to the increasing abundance of OV* sites. These vacancies require at least one O2 molecule to be adsorbed for O-H bond scission in CH3CH2OH to occur. To understand the impact of Cu on H2O formation (R12) in Au/LaMnCuO3, we performed a crystal orbital Hamilton population (COHP) analysis of the Mn–O, Cu–O, Au–O, Au–H and O–H bonds for the initial state (IS), transition state (TS) and final state (FS) of H2O formation on the Au/LaMnO3 and Au/LaMnCuO3 models. The IS, TS, and FS geometries show that H2O formation is a concerted reaction, where the Au-H, Au-O, and Mn–O/Cu–O bonds are broken while a HO–H bond is formed. The integrated COHP (iCOHP) was used to quantitatively assess the strength of these bonds in the IS and the TS. The iCOHP values and the difference in iCOHP between the TS and IS, defined as ∆iCOHP = iCOHPTS – iCOHPIS, are listed in Table 4 . A positive ∆iCOHP value indicates a decrease in bond strength, while a negative value indicates an increase in bond strength. Our analysis shows that, going from the IS to the TS in the elementary H2O formation reaction step (R12), the Cu–O and Au–H bonds in Au/LaMnCuO3 are weakened more than the Mn–O and Au–H bonds in Au/LaMnO3. Conversely, the decrease in the Au–O bond strength between the IS and TS is more pronounced in Au/LaMnO3 than in Au/LaMnCuO3. The resulting HO–H bond in this step is stronger in Au/LaMnCuO3. Overall, these findings align with the lower barrier of H2O formation in Au/LaMnCuO3. The ∆iCOHP values for the Mn–O and Cu–O bonds in Table 4 help to understand this: the Cu–O interaction is notably weaker than the Mn–O interaction, in line with the lower reactivity of Cu ions with a higher d-band occupancy than Mn ions. Thus, substituting Mn with Cu destabilizes surface oxygen atoms, facilitating H2O formation. 3.5 Comparison of experimental and computational findings Our experimental efforts demonstrated that doping LaMnO3 perovskite with a small amount of Cu (LaMn0.75Cu0.25O3) leads to a reduction in surface area while increasing crystal size and enhancing the stability of Mn and Cu cations against reduction, thereby generating a suitable support for AuNPs to achieve a highly active, selective and stable catalyst for the oxidation of ethanol to acetaldehyde. With increasing amount of Cu, the catalytic activity sharply declines, reaching levels comparable to the undoped Au/LaMnO3 catalyst. These Cu-doped compositions maintain a high AC selectivity (> 95%) in a wide temperature range. These results highlight the beneficial role of Cu doping in LaMnO3 for selective ethanol oxidation. The superior catalytic performance of the Au/LaMn0.75Cu0.25O3 catalyst can be attributed to the synergy between Cu and Mn cations in the perovskite surface, close to the Au nanoparticles. We speculate that the dominant factor to explain the highest AC yield for Au/LaMn0.75Cu0.25O3 is the optimum amount of Cu+-O-Mn2+ sites, which in conjunction with AuNPs catalyze the selective oxidation ethanol to AC. When more Cu is doped into the surface, the number of Cu2+-O-Cu2+ site increases, rendering the Cu too susceptible to reduction and Cu0 formation. Our computational study comprehensively explains the ethanol oxidation mechanism on Au clusters supported by Cu-doped LaMnO3 perovskite. The reaction rate for Au/LaMnO3 and Au/LaMnCuO3 is controlled by H2O formation in the second part of the catalytic cycle (SII) with activation energies of 1.67 and 0.72 eV, respectively. For Au/La2CuO4, the reaction rate is controlled by α-C–H bond scission in adsorbed ethoxy in the first part of the cycle (SI), which has an activation energy of 0.91 eV. At typical reaction temperatures below 330 °C, the predicted ethanol conversion rate follows the order Au/LaMnO3 < Au/La2CuO4 < Au/LaMnCuO3 (Fig. 9(A)), which aligns with the experimental trends at temperatures below 200 °C (Fig. 4(A)). The predicted reaction rate for Au/LaMnCuO3 is significantly higher than the experimental data. This discrepancy can be attributed to the highly idealized nature of the Au/LaMnCuO3 model, which assumes a well-defined surface with one-Cu-substituted LaMnO3 and the presence of Au8 clusters. In practice, the Au/LaMnCuO3 catalyst exhibits a much higher Cu content and larger AuNP. Therefore, the predicted reaction rate from microkinetics simulations for the Cu-doped model emphasizes the impact on the reaction mechanism in an idealized manner, allowing only a semi-quantitative interpretation of the results [75]. To gain a deeper understanding into the catalytic behavior of the prepared catalysts (Au/LaMnO3, Au/LaMn0.75Cu0.25O3, Au/LaMn0.5Cu0.5O3, and Au/La2CuO4), we compared the adsorption energies of O2 and ethanol on the Au/LaMnO3, Au/LaMnCuO3 and Au/La2CuO4 models (Fig. 8 and Table 3). The O2 adsorption energies (R7) decrease according to Au/LaMnO3 (∆E ads = –1.85 eV) > Au/LaMnCuO3 (∆E ads = –1.27 eV) > Au/La2CuO4 (∆E ads = –0.95 eV). The ethanol adsorption energies (R8) decrease according to Au/LaMnO3 (∆E ads = –1.18 eV) > Au/LaMnCuO3 (∆E ads = –0.86 eV) > Au/La2CuO4 (∆E ads = –0.76 eV). Thus, the adsorption of both reactants becomes weaker with increasing Cu content of the perovskite support. Combined with the observed trends in oxygen vacancy formation energies and H2O formation barriers, this points to an optimum Cu doping level, which leads to the highest availability of adjacent Cu-O-Mn active sites. To understand the synergy from the electronic structure point of view, we determined the spin magnetic moments on Mn and Cu in stoichiometric and defective models of Au/LaMnO3 and Au/LaMnCuO3. The location of Mn and Cu atoms and the oxygen vacancies are given in Fig. S13. Table S3 summarizes the spin magnetic moments and oxidation states of Mn and Cu atoms near the oxygen vacancies. For the stoichiometric Au8/LaMnO3 model, the spin magnetic moments of the two Mn atoms M1 and M2 are 3.96 and 4.13 µB, implying a +3 oxidation state [76]. Removal of a surface oxygen atom in Au/LaMnO3 increases the spin magnetic moments to 4.42 and 4.44 µB, corresponding to the reduction of the adjacent Mn3+ ions to Mn2+. For the stoichiometric Au/LaMnCuO3 model, the spin magnetic moments of Mn and Cu are 3.96 and –0.47 µB, respectively Mn3+ and Cu2+ [76,77]. After removing the surface oxygen atom, these values change to 4.47 µB for Mn and 0.09 µB for Cu, meaning that the adjacent Mn3+ and Cu2+ ions are reduced to Mn2+ and Cu+. These results strongly point to the role of adjacent Cu+-OV-Mn2+ sites, where O2 is adsorbed and activated via a two-electron-transfer process to form O2 2–. Kinetically, the weaker Cu-O bond compared to the Mn-O bond lowers the barrier of the rate-controlling step for H2O formation in the second part of the catalytic cycle. This barrier is further reduced when more Cu is doped in the surface, which leads to a shift in the rate-controlling step to α-C-H dissociation of the ethoxy species during the first part of the catalytic cycle. Experimentally, we observe that a Cu content that is too high leads to Cu2+ reduction to Cu0. A low amount of Cu doping likely avoids the formation of unstable Cu2+-O-Cu2+ motifs. Cu2+-O-Mn3+ motifs, in combination with highly dispersed Au, contribute to the outstanding performance of Au/LaMn0.75Cu0.25O3. 4 Conclusions In summary, we present a novel application of Cu-doped LaMnO3 perovskite as support for AuNPs, demonstrating its high efficiency and stability as a catalyst for the gas-phase aerobic oxidation of ethanol to acetaldehyde. The Au/LaMn0.75Cu0.25O3 catalyst achieved a maximum yield of 95% at 225 °C and maintained this activity for 80 h without deactivation. In contrast, catalysts with higher Cu content showed significantly lower activity, primarily due to the facile reduction to Cu0 during ethanol oxidation. The enhanced catalytic performance is attributed to synergistic interactions between Au0, Mn2+, and Cu+. Theoretical calculations indicate that Cu doping in LaMnO3 creates adjacent Cu+-OV-Mn2+ sites near the AuNPs, facilitating O2 activation to form O2 2– and subsequently activating ethanol’s O-H and α-C-H bonds. As a result, the Au/LaMnCuO3 model catalyst displays a much lower barrier for the rate-controlling step of H2O formation in the second part of the catalytic cycle compared to the Au/LaMnO3 model. Moreover, replacing all Mn with Cu further lowers this barrier, shifting the rate-controlling step to α-C-H dissociation in adsorbed ethoxy during the first part of the catalytic cycle. Both experimental and computational results underscore the beneficial effects of doping with a small amount of Cu. coredata.dc:description: Gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) supported on the Cu-doped LaMnO3 perovskites exhibit strong Au-Mn-Cu synergy in the aerobic oxidation of gaseous ethanol to acetaldehyde (AC). The Au/LaMnCuO3 catalysts achieve AC yields exceeding 90% and a space-time yield of 715 gAC gAu –1 h–1 at 225 °C, outperforming reported catalysts. The outstanding performance is attributed to adjacent Cu+ and Mn2+ ions in the perovskite surface, which, together with nearby AuNPs, contribute to the high activity and stability. The best-performing catalyst contains a Cu/Mn ratio of 1/3 in the perovskite. Doping too much Cu into the perovskite leads to metallic Cu, suppressing catalyst performance. Density functional theory (reaction energetics, electronic structure analysis) and microkinetics simulations aided in understanding the synergy between Cu and Mn and the role of AuNPs. The reaction involves two H abstraction steps: (1) O–H cleavage of adsorbed ethanol by the basic perovskite lattice oxygen atom and (2) α-C-H cleavage by AuNPs, yielding AC and adsorbed water. Molecular O2 adsorbs in the oxygen vacancy (OV) formed by water removal, generating a peroxide anion (O2 2–) as the activated oxygen species. In the second part of the catalytic cycle, the basic O2 2– species abstracts the H atom from another ethanol molecule, followed by α-C-H cleavage by AuNPs, AC production, and water removal. Water formation in the second part of the catalytic cycle is the rate-controlling step for Au/LaMnO3 and Au/LaMnCuO3 models. Moderate Cu doping enhances the essential Cu+-OV-Mn2+ sites and lowers the barrier for water formation due to the weaker Cu–O bond than the Mn–O bond. In contrast, excessive Cu doping creates unstable Cu2+-O-Cu2+ sites and shifts the barrier to the α-C-H cleavage.
